messageBody:
On Tue, Sep 20, 2005 at 03:27:21AM -0700, John H. E. wrote:

> --- Cedric Beust <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> > Oops, sorry. I kept reading "CLDC" whenever you wrote "CDC". Reflection
> > is definitely an option then.
>
> OK, good :)
>
> > I still think that there is little point in testing on the device
> > itself. Or rather, that it makes little sense as long as you don't have
> a > set of tests on the emulator.
>
> Uhm... not sure I follow. I presume testing on the device itself would be
> better than no testing at all, e.g. in the event that you don't have a
> good enough emulator, or emulator tests.
>

My colleagues and I are currently developing testing techniques for
resource constrained environments. In the context of Java one of the
main problems that we have encountered is that the native code bodies
consume significant amounts of memory and then cause frequent
invocations of the garbage collector.

We are using the Jikes RVM to evaluate some of our hypotheses. While
the work that we are doing is not all directly relevant to software
testing practicioners (yet!), I thought that some people might be
interested in visiting the below URL and then contacting me for more
details.

http://cs.allegheny.edu/~gkapfham/research/juggernaut/

Kind Regards,

greg
